Chapter 1 covers the components, safety considerations, and types of domestic gas-fired refrigerators.

THERMOSTAT BULB OR SENSOR:

Bulb of thermostatic valve is in shape of wound capillary tube and is positioned at specific point on evaporator (usually the fins) of refrigerator box. Modern bulbs are designed so that last 4 in (10 cm) of capillary act as sensing element.

In refrigerators with electronic controls, sensors are used to determine temperature and transmit necessary information to manage all system functions. Refer to specific manufacturer's information for each model of fridge.

CARBON MONOXIDE SENSOR:

Some refrigeration units include carbon monoxide (CO) sensor integrated into millivolt (thermocouple-driven) safety valve, to alert user if CO levels exceed allowable 50 ppm (parts per million), and shut down burner entirely if there are dangerous levels of CO.

These refrigeration units are battery-operated, and their testing procedures include both battery check and CO sensor check. Check manufacturer instructions on how to test this sensor. Newer models feature disconnect that allows separation of CO sensor unit from appliance if there is need to service unit.

IMPORTANT: Propane refrigerators installed in dwellings prior to adoption of 2010 CSA B149.1 Code, which required they be of direct-vented type, must have CO safety shut-off system.

MANUAL GAS VALVE:

Manual gas valve consists of main housing and manually activated on/off valve. Manual gas valve is main connection between gas supply and refrigerator.

TYPES OF SYSTEMS AND SAFETY CONSIDERATIONS:

Gas technician/fitter may be required to service system that provides heat to absorption refrigerators, with gas burner and its heat exchanger falling within expertise of gas technician/fitter.

IMPORTANT: Gas technician/fitter is not refrigeration technician, so refrigeration components should be left to person qualified in that trade.

LITHIUM-BROMIDE SYSTEMS:

Water-lithium-bromide system is similar to ammonia-water system. However, instead of cooling fins on condenser and absorber, circulation water tubes carry away heat.

Also, water-lithium-bromide system does not use hydrogen at high pressure to carry refrigerant vapour. Instead, it operates at very low pressures to enable temperature in evaporator and refrigerator cabinet to fall to required level of coldness.

Larger applications primarily use these systems, and these are covered in unit "Gas-fired air conditioning".

SAFETY:

Before working with these systems (and chemicals), refer to company policy and your supervisor.

LITHIUM-BROMIDE SOLUTION IS:
- Non-toxic
- Non-flammable
- Non-explosive
- Chemically stable

However, solution becomes corrosive when exposed to air and may irritate skin, eyes, and mucous membranes.

EMERGENCY FIRST AID (lithium-bromide):
If you come in contact with lithium-bromide solution:
- Flush contacted area with lukewarm water for at least 15 min
- Remove contaminated clothing (while taking care not to spread chemical)
- If contamination is extensive, remove clothing under running water
- Seek medical attention if irritation persists

AMMONIA ABSORPTION:

Ammonia absorption cooling unit is sealed unit not meant to be tampered with in any way. Cooling unit contains ammonia, sodium chromate, and hydrogen at pressure of 300 to 350 psi (2068 to 2413 kPa).

SAFETY WARNING:
Do not drill, weld, or cut cooling unit. Any rupture of cooling unit will immediately engulf area in ammonia and hydrogen (displacing air).

Hydrogen is flammable, and ammonia is intensely irritating gas that can render person unconscious.

EMERGENCY FIRST AID (ammonia):
Keywords for first aid involving ammonia are, simply, air and water.

If you inhale ammonia or come in contact with liquid ammonia, immediately:
- Get fresh air; and
- Flush any affected area of your body or clothing with plenty of water

SODIUM CHROMATE:
Sodium chromate is carcinogen.

If you get sodium chromate on you:
- Wash thoroughly with soap and water; and
- If you experience lingering effects or have concerns about exposure to cooling unit materials, seek medical attention

When working on or changing cooling unit, never allow yourself to be cornered in small area; always have means of exit. Although cooling units are very sturdy, all it takes is one weak point (deteriorated pipe, for example) to create problem.

CAUTION: If cooling unit ruptures, stay away from area and wait for ammonia to dissipate. Call for assistance.

THREE-WAY REFRIGERATORS:

Three-way refrigerators are combination gas-electrical absorption refrigerators that operate on following basis:

HEAT SOURCE OPTIONS:
- 120-V HEATER: Current from 120 V AC power supply
- 12-V HEATER: Current from battery
- GAS BURNER: Propane from tank or natural gas from supply line

Use of AES system means circuit board in refrigerator selects most appropriate (available) heat source.

AES SELECTION LOGIC:
- IF 120V is available: Refrigerator will select it
- IF 120V is unavailable: Next power source in order is 12V
  (Refrigerator can only utilize 12V under certain conditions, namely, if vehicle is running and batteries are being charged)
- IF 120V is unavailable AND conditions for 12-V operation are not being met: Refrigerator will operate on propane

SAFETY:
For three-way refrigerators, adhere to all safety requirements for electricity and gas. When working with electricity, wear protective equipment required for specific application.

WIRING AND SCHEMATIC DIAGRAMS:

Manufacturer's literature for three-way refrigerators often includes wiring diagrams and schematics that you can use for installation and troubleshooting purposes.

ELECTRONIC THREE-WAY REFRIGERATORS:

Electronic control of three-way refrigerator serves as gateway for voltage distribution to various components of refrigerator managing inputs, outputs, monitoring, and diagnostic functions. Meanwhile, power board oversees and controls all operations.

Inputs, outputs, monitoring information, and diagnostic functions are communicated through optical control assembly. Wire harness interfacing power board with optical control assembly is "foamed" into cabinet.

GAS ABSORPTION HEAT PUMPS (GAHP):

Gas absorption heat pump (GAHP) operates on same principle as ammonia-water refrigerators, but has added capability of being reversible and serving as heat source.

HEATING MODE (winter):
When operating in heating mode, appliance uses absorption cooling cycle to recover heat from outside environment, which, added to heat produced by combustion of natural/liquefied petroleum gas, is transferred into exchanger and then into environment to be heated. Heat output is used to supply low-temperature hot water for space heating, similar to traditional boiler.

COOLING MODE:
Same unit is suitable for cooling by reversing absorption cycle using outside air for heat rejection in cooling mode.

OPERATING EFFICIENCY:
Although GAHPs tend to have lower operating efficiencies compared to electric heat pumps, they can achieve lower operating costs depending on relative costs of energy sources. In general terms, absorption heat pumps are hydronic systems (similar to outside boiler) as they heat or cool (or both) water as it is required.

SUMMER OPERATION:
- Air cooling water down to 37.4°F
- Cooling with ambient air up to 37.4°F
- Gas input

WINTER OPERATION:
- High efficiency heating water up to 140°F
- Heat recovery from ambient air down to -20°F
- Gas input

TYPICAL COMPACT ROOFTOP UNIT:
- Gas input: 95,000 Btu/h
- Heating capacity: around 120,000 Btu/h
- Cooling capacity: nearly 60,000 Btu/h

For more information on larger commercial systems, refer to unit "Gas-fired air conditioning".

Chapter 2 covers installation requirements and procedures for domestic gas-fired refrigerators.

ROOF VENT:

Roof vent, which completes venting system, also ensures good air flow. Roof vent is centered over cooling unit and is at least as long as cooling unit is wide.

DIRECT-VENTED MODELS:

Direct-vent (DV) appliance is also known as "sealed-combustion" appliance. In these appliances, venting system draws in combustion air and vents all flue gas directly to outdoors. These units have clearance requirements for air flow and heat removal, and plastic venting system must be of ULC S636-approved material installed as per vent manufacturer's instructions.

DV refrigerator must be installed in accordance with manufacturer instructions. Following information identifies some of common concerns.

NEVER VENT TO SIDE OF APPLIANCE:
Vents must terminate directly from back of appliance and out through exterior wall.

HIGH-WIND TERMINATION:
Ideally, terminate hood vents in sheltered location not affected by high winds. If this is not possible, use manufacturer's high-wind termination hood.

SEALED COMBUSTION VENT IN RVs:

Sealed combustion vent design, commonly used in RVs, consists of two parts:

UPPER AND LOWER VENTS:
These vents, as in other designs, use internal air from vehicle to exhaust heat away from condenser. If either of these two vents is obstructed or interior of vehicle is extremely hot, cooling unit does not perform efficiently because condenser is unable to cool sufficiently.

SEALED COMBUSTION SECTION:
Sealed combustion section consists of two flex tubes, which link burner assembly to outside vent housing:
- LARGER FLEX TUBE: Fresh-air intake, which feeds outside air directly to burner
- SMALLER FLEX TUBE: Exhaust tube, which is used to dissipate products of combustion from boiler tube

It is important to note contour of two tubes as well as outside vent housing.

IMPORTANT INSTALLATION POINTS:
- If tubes are not installed correctly, it is very difficult to keep burner lit
- Without trap in tubes, there will be backdraft into burner box, causing flame to extinguish
- In case of exhaust tube, there could be buildup of condensation within tube and, if it is not properly bent, condensation will drain backward, drip onto burner, and extinguish flame

VENT HOUSING:
Vent housing for sealed combustion vent must not follow contour of vehicle and must be less than 90° to ground to allow condensation to flow out of housing.

Some manufacturers design vent housings to include separator plate to prevent exhaust air from being channelled back into fresh-air intake.

INSTALLING THE REFRIGERATOR:

Refrigerator installed in mobile home or RV must comply with CSA Z240.4.1 or CSA Z240.4.2 and be installed in accordance with manufacturer instructions.

For installations in other types of dwellings, refrigerator must be installed according to:
- CSA B149.1
- CSA B149.2
- Manufacturer's certified installation instructions

IN ALL CASES, REFRIGERATOR MUST BE INSTALLED:
- On flat and level floor
- Away from direct sunlight
- Away from any object that may radiate heat

IN ALL CASES:
- Refrigerator should be located in well-ventilated but not drafty place
- It is extremely important that refrigerator be installed level (because this type of refrigerator is non-mechanical and operates on basis of gravity)
- If unit is to be built-in, refer to manufacturer specifications for clearances
- Keep refrigerator free from combustible materials, gasoline, and other flammable vapours and liquids

GAS CONNECTIONS:

Propane-fired refrigerators are usually made to be connected with 3/8 in (10 mm) copper tube (free from sharp corners and curves) that is mounted on conical coupling connected to manual shut-off valve. Copper tube (feed pipe) must be placed in way that will avoid damage if refrigerator is removed from its compartment.

In addition, keep following in mind:
- When connecting refrigerator to its gas supply, check required pressure (as marked on appliance rating plate)
- Never connect propane gas cylinder directly to refrigerator (i.e., without regulator)

IMPORTANT: Check sealing of all joints using approved leak-detection solution.

FLUE AND VENTILATION SYSTEM:

Flue directs hot gases around and away from generating unit. Occasionally, these flues may be restricted due to:
- Placing refrigerator too close to wall
- Placing objects over opening
- Having obstruction fall into it

Keep flue clean to ensure proper functioning of refrigerator. For information on procedure for cleaning flue, see Chapter 3.

CONTROLS:

Most refrigerators have controls located on console at base of refrigerator and connected to control devices in rear of unit.

Microprocessor-based systems have digital display for control console that is located at top front or bottom of refrigerator, depending on size and style.

CO SENSOR WITH SAFETY SHUT-OFF:

Some models of gas refrigerators are equipped with CO sensor and/or safety shut-off device. These components must be installed in accordance with manufacturer instructions. Alarm system is designed to emit loud, irritating noise. If very high CO level is detected, CO alarm will activate within few minutes.

After positioning and mounting detector, ensure it is connected to appliance. For some models, there is matching plug at lower back of fridge. Other models may require thermocouple interrupter body and adapter.

INSTALLATION PROCEDURE:

Following procedure is one example of manufacturer's installation instructions:

1. DETERMINE APPROPRIATE LOCATION AND INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:
   a) Read installation and operating instructions
   b) Prepare gas supply and electrical connections in accordance with code requirements and authority having jurisdiction

2. MOVE APPLIANCE TO AREA WHERE IT WILL BE INSTALLED:
   a) Ensure that there is adequate ventilation for condenser cooling
   b) Ensure that venting is secured and tight

3. POSITION REFRIGERATOR IN SELECTED POSITION:
   a) Rotate levelling bolts under unit until refrigerator is level
   b) Remove it from its location

4. Use certified flexible-type metal connector of sufficient length (see Clause 6.21.3 of CSA B149.1) to connect gas supply to manual shut-off valve

5. Connect pressure gauge at pressure tap of thermostatic valve; ensure that pressure is correct for appliance

6. Perform leak test for all connections, as required by applicable code

TO CHECK OPERATION:

1. Operate refrigerator according to instructions; allow it to operate for at least 30 min

2. During this 30-min period, use liquid solution or leak-detection device:
   a) To check connections for leaks; and
   b) To check from gas inlet to orifice spud

3. Check reading on pressure gauge (refer to manufacturer instructions):
   - IF appliance is only one operating on line: Operating pressure should not be higher than 11 in w.c. (2.75 kPa)
   - IF other appliances are on same line: Pressure should not fall below 10 in w.c. (2.5 kPa)

4. Test liquefied petroleum gas safety shut-off system in accordance with manufacturer instructions

5. Turn gas off at control; leave manual shut-off valve open

6. Replace plug on thermostatic valve

7. Replace burner box

8. You can now install refrigerator in selected location; while doing so, make sure no kinks form in flexible connector

9. Set refrigerator to normal operation

INSTRUCTIONS TO CUSTOMER:

After installation, cover following points with customer to ensure they understand operation and will be able to pinpoint potential problems. Also encourage customer to read owner's manual in its entirety.

- Inform customer that absorption refrigerator operates noiselessly, which means they will not be able to tell simply by listening whether or not it is working
- Explain CO sensor test procedures to customer (if their unit came with CO sensor and safety shut-off)
- Inform customer about cleaning procedures and unit's warranty
- Advise customer to keep owner's manual close by for handy reference
- Instruct customer about defrosting refrigerator and freezer compartments
- Inform customer that efficiency of unit will be reduced if refrigerator is overfilled
- Explain to customer that unit should be left empty to operate for about 6 to 8 h after light-up to enable temperature to decrease

DEFROSTING:

After some time, ice will begin to collect on fins of evaporator to point where it will reduce efficiency of refrigerator. At this point, defrosting is needed.

Take note of following:
- Defrosting should be done when 50% of space between fins is taken up by ice
- Interval between instances of defrosting can vary considerably (depending on climate and extent of use)

Most new refrigerator designs incorporate automatic defrost, during which refrigerator periodically runs through defrost cycle, as it is required by control system.

MANUAL DEFROSTING PROCEDURE (typical):

1. Remove food from main compartment or freezer
2. Set thermostat knob to defrost position
3. Leave unit for approximately 2 h
4. During this process, refrigerator will continue to work on low flame providing refrigeration capacity for freezer
5. Ice on fins will melt, flow down drain to rear of refrigerator, and drain into number of small containers, where it will evaporate
6. Check fins to make sure they are free of ice
7. Readjust thermostat to its usual setting

FREEZER DEFROSTING:
Freezer will need defrosting less frequently (e.g., every two months or so). However, when there is large buildup of ice in freezer compartment:

1. Turn off gas at selector and remove all food
2. Remove all loose components from refrigerator (e.g., racks, drawers, batteries for lights)
3. Turn drip pan around so that drain hole is towards front of refrigerator then place suitable container under it to catch runoff from melting ice
4. Use plastic scraper to remove ice as it melts
5. Leave doors open until all of ice has melted then remove container
6. Return drip tray to its normal position

Chapter 3 covers maintenance, servicing, and troubleshooting procedures for domestic gas-fired refrigerators.

MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS:

To ensure that domestic gas-fired refrigerator operates properly, it must:
- Be level
- Have correct input
- Have proper air circulation to dissipate heat generated

If these three conditions are successfully met, refrigerator should operate successfully.

CLEANING AND SERVICING:

To maintain their safe and efficient operation, gas-fired absorption refrigerator should be serviced and maintained twice year — preferably before season of continued use and especially if refrigerator has not been in use for some time.

When servicing gas-fired absorption refrigerator, ensure that its gas supply pressure is correct.

CONDENSER FINS AND ABSORBER:

Periodically cleaning fins on condenser is essential to ensure good heat removal from these surfaces.

To check and clean condenser fins and absorber:

1. Move refrigerator away from its permanent location; make sure that flexible connector does not kink
2. Clean any dust buildup on absorber and condenser (which can lessen heat transfer and impair performance):
   a) Remove dust from refrigerator and enclosure
   b) Use clean paintbrush to clean condenser

FLUE SYSTEM:

After period in operation, flue may require cleaning. Dirty flue causes reduction in rapid heat transfer from gas flame to generator body.

Periodic cleaning of flue is needed to:
- Ensure proper refrigeration
- Reduce gas consumption
- Prevent incomplete combustion and production of CO

Following procedure for cleaning flue is typical. In all cases, place paper or cloth under refrigerator to collect dirt or debris.

1. Cover burner with cloth
2. Loosen and remove flue extension
3. Remove baffle assembly. Clean and inspect assembly. Baffle may contain burnt dust and light surface corrosion, but tip must be intact and not corroded. Soot must not be present (if it is, it indicates incomplete combustion). If you find soot, contact dealer or manufacturer.
4. Run brush through flame tube. Soot must be absent.
5. Reassemble baffle, checking its extension if necessary
6. Assemble flue extension, making sure that wire of baffle fits into slot of baffle
7. Remove cloth from burner
8. Reinstall burner box
9. Check operation of refrigerator

SERVICING BASICS:

When servicing absorption refrigerator, it is crucial to maintain balance of these three factors:
- Heat input
- Air circulation
- Levelling

PROPER HEAT INPUT:

Manufacturer designs refrigerator so that:
- Maximum input setting is high enough for unit to respond quickly to added loads, but not so high that generator gets scorched or blistered
- Minimum input setting is low enough to prevent overcooling but not so low as to allow flame to be blown out by drafts

To ensure proper heat input:

1. Check gas pressure using manometer at pressure tap (on thermostatic valve); correct it (if necessary) by adjusting regulator at cylinder
2. If orifice is partially blocked, clean or replace it
3. Clean or replace filter on gas control inlet side
4. If flame is impinging on surface or is burning yellow, you will need to clean generator and flue passages to remove soot and ensure rapid heat transfer. Be careful not to damage surfaces of generator.

PROPER AIR CIRCULATION:

For proper air circulation, air flow to and from unit must be unrestricted.

To achieve this:
- Ensure that back of refrigerator is required distance from wall; and
- Check that foreign objects have not fallen into space behind refrigerator

Cooling fins of both condenser and absorber must be free of dirt and lint (as this would hamper flow of air and release of heat to atmosphere).

PROPER LEVELLING:

Keep system level during installation and maintenance (this enables liquids to flow in their proper direction so that heat is absorbed and released according to design of system).

It is important that evaporator is level to ensure that liquid ammonia spreads out over large area (this allows heat to be drawn efficiently from refrigerator cabinet).

If unit has been unused for some time, it may fail to start cooling on first try due to empty traps and ammonia vapour blocking tubes in places that affect system's operation. To overcome this, some manufacturers recommend:

1. Shut unit off for several hours to allow all of ammonia vapour to condense, flow back to generator, and fill liquid traps
2. After about 10 min of operation, tilt unit to left for 30 sec, then to right for 30 sec
3. Repeat previous step three or four times, then put refrigerator in upright, level position. Unless unit is defective, it should begin freezing at this point.

MAXIMUM OFF-LEVEL OPERATION LIMITS:
Refrigerant circulates through cooling unit by gravity flow, so refrigerator must be operated in level position. Its operation off level will affect flow of refrigerant through cooling system.

Maximum off-level operation limits are:
- 3° side-to-side; and
- 6° front-to-back

Exceeding maximum off-level limits can permanently damage cooling unit.

NOTE: In mobile gas-fired refrigerators, cooling unit and its performance are not affected when vehicle is in motion.

TESTING COMPONENTS:

Following information on testing components is intended to provide broad understanding of basic process. Manufacturer instructions on component testing will be provided in service manual that comes with unit.

CO SENSOR WITH SAFETY SHUT-OFF:

For units supplied with CO sensor, manufacturers recommend testing operation of alarm at least once per week during use and/or if appliance has been turned off for some time.

Following is typical procedure on how to test CO sensor:

1. Push and hold test button until you hear "beep" then release button
2. Unit will test measurement circuit for correct operation
3. At end of test, unit will beep for three seconds to confirm test and then resume normal operation

This test will shut off gas supply to appliance, so it will need to be relit before resuming operation.

FLAME-FAILURE DEVICE:

Check operation of flame-failure device as follows:

1. With refrigerator running, set thermostat to its coldest setting
2. Close and then immediately open selector valve. (Flame will go out, but gas supply will continue to flow.)
3. Listen carefully. In about 30 to 40 sec, you will hear slight but distinct "click" signifying that valve has closed.

REPLACING COMPONENTS:

ORIFICE HOUSING:

Using two open-ended spanners to disassemble nipple holder can help to remove orifice. When replacing orifice housing:

1. Remove injector piece and check for obstructions
2. Clean piece with alcohol and compressed air
3. Before reassembling, gently tap on gas tube leading to burner few times to loosen any lint collected in tube
4. Reassemble and carefully tighten

BURNER:

Depending on type of refrigerator, burner assembly can be either gas-only or combination gas-electric unit.

To replace gas-only burner:
1. Remove cover by unscrewing screws
2. Unscrew burner jet
3. Remove burner by unscrewing mounting screw
4. Insert replacement burner (of same make and model)
5. Reassemble mounting screw and cover

To replace gas-electric burner:
1. Remove covers by unscrewing screws
2. Disconnect heater cords at terminal blocks (note their locations for reassembly)
3. Carefully remove capillary tube from evaporator to avoid damage
4. Remove screws
5. Release burner housing from flue by turning lever outward and to right
6. Pull equipment out of cabinet
7. Replace burner (with one of same make and model)

ADDITIONAL COMPONENTS:

Following components also affect overall performance of refrigerator and should be tested and serviced during call. Refer to manufacturer's service manual for cleaning, testing, and servicing instructions:

- Cabinet and absorber fan motors
- Door switches
- Cabinet lights
- Heaters
- Defrost switch
- Door seal
- Refrigeration unit
- Defrost heater and safety switch

TROUBLESHOOTING PROCEDURES:

Procedure for troubleshooting gas-fired absorption refrigerator is similar to procedure for other gas-fired appliances.

When responding to customer trouble call:

1. Clarify customer's complaint by asking questions and getting as much information as possible
2. Interpret customer's complaint using manufacturer's service manuals
3. Identify potential faults that could be causing problem and test components that may be at fault

TROUBLESHOOTING TIPS:

Following tips are specific to gas-fired refrigerators:

CHECK FOR SODIUM CHROMATE:
This can be identified by its bright yellow colour. Some other points about this substance:
- Sodium chromate solidifies when exposed to air
- If sodium chromate is visible on outside tubes, it indicates that there is refrigerant leak

CHECK TEMPERATURE OF UNIT:

- IF cooling unit is functioning properly: There will be even heat on both boiler section and middle of absorber coils
- IF boiler section is hot, and absorber section is warm: Evaporator unit is blocked
- IF boiler section is warm, and absorber is hot: Hydrogen circuit has lost its charge of hydrogen and boiled ammonia is circulating through cooling unit (as there is no hydrogen to cause it to evaporate)
- IF inside of fridge is warm, but there is frost on condenser fins: There is internal leak in evaporator

GRADUAL DECREASE IN COOLING EFFICIENCY:

Gradual decrease in cooling efficiency is not clear indication of cooling system failure.

Other factors that affect cooling efficiency include:
- Ventilation
- Heat input
- Not-level operation
- Lack of appropriate service and maintenance
- Inadequate repairs
- Unauthorized field modifications

If any of these exist and are not corrected, replacement cooling unit will also perform inefficiently or fail.

Best approach when dealing with gradual decrease in cooling is step-by-step troubleshooting. It is important to appreciate that cooling unit is working, it is just not working efficiently.

Troubleshooting should always begin by checking ventilation, followed by thorough check of cooling unit and heat sources. In majority of reported cases, problem is related to installation of unit, which has since hindered cooling unit ventilation. Ambient air temperature can also play significant role if unit was not installed correctly.

Incorrect installation leads to poor ventilation, resulting in suboptimal cooling performance. When diagnosing cooling unit with poor cooling performance, consider unit's service and maintenance history. History and scope of previous service work can often point directly to cause (and solution) of cooling issue.

Before troubleshooting can begin, cooling unit must reach its normal operating temperature, process that typically takes about four hours, though exact time will depend on ambient air temperature.

For more detailed information on common issues and their causes, refer to troubleshooting chart.

Chapter 1                    
Absorption Refrigerators: 
Operation and Principles
Absorption refrigerators have no moving parts, are noiseless, and require 
only a small flame to operate. These unique refrigeration systems use a 
sealed pressure system where refrigerant travels through the system, 
absorbing and releasing heat at key areas to cool the refrigerator and 
freezer compartments.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Basic Components of Absorption Refrigerators
Generator (Boiler)
The heat energy source 
that begins and maintains 
the operating cycle. The 
generator heats the 
refrigerant, turning it into a 
vapor so it separates from 
the water solution and 
travels to the condenser.
Condenser
Removes heat from the 
vaporized refrigerant, 
causing it to condense into 
a liquid. Condenser fins 
transfer heat from the 
fridge to the condenser 
coils.
Evaporator
The liquid refrigerant 
encounters pressurized 
hydrogen and evaporates. 
This heat transfer makes 
the tubes cold, cooling the 
refrigerator.
Absorber
Consists of a coil and tank. 
The liquid inside attracts 
and absorbs the refrigerant 
from the evaporator, 
storing it until the 
generator begins the cycle 
again.
Learning Objectives
Describe Basic 
Operating Principles
Understand how absorption 
refrigeration systems 
function without moving 
parts
Describe Generator 
Components
Learn about the key 
components in gas-fired 
refrigerator generators
Understand System Types and Safety
Identify different absorption system types and their safety 
considerations
Key Terminology
Term
Abbreviation
Definition
Automatic energy selector 
system
AES
A system that lets the circuit 
board in the refrigerator select 
the most appropriate available 
heat source

Condenser fins
Transfer heat from the fridge

ratio

Basic Operating Principles
An absorption-refrigeration system uses three key elements to create a 
cooling effect:
Refrigerant
The substance that absorbs 
and releases heat during the 
refrigeration cycle
Adsorbent
The material that absorbs 
the refrigerant during part 
of the cycle
Heat
The energy source that drives the refrigeration process
Unlike compression refrigeration systems, the basic absorption cycle 
uses no moving parts. The cycle depends on the action and reaction 
between the refrigerant and the adsorbent under various pressure and 
temperature conditions in a sealed system.
Cooling and Condensing Effects
Cooling Effect
The system makes use of the cooling effect that results 
when liquids flash to a gaseous state. This is similar to 
blowing on the back of your hand when there is water on it - 
the blowing causes the water to evaporate and your hand 
feels slightly cold.
Condensing Effect
The condensing effect occurs when heat is removed from a 
gas, changing it back into a liquid. This process happens in 
the condenser section of the refrigerator, where heat is 
transferred away from the refrigerant.
Cutaway View of Propane 
Refrigerator
This cutaway view shows the main components of a propane refrigerator. 
Ammonia is liquefied in the finned condenser coil at the top rear of the 
refrigerator. The liquid ammonia then flows into the evaporator (inside 
the freezer section) and is exposed to circulating flow of hydrogen gas, 
which causes the ammonia to evaporate, creating a cold condition in the 
freezer.
Refrigerant Flow Circuits
Solution Circuit
Contains the ammonia-water solution that circulates 
between generator and absorber
Condensing Circuit
Where ammonia vapor is cooled and condensed into liquid
Hydrogen Circuit
Where hydrogen gas helps evaporate the ammonia to 
create cooling
Flow of Refrigerant: Step 1
Generator (Boiler) Heats Strong 
Solution
The perk tube is provided with a strong 
ammonia solution (high percentage of 
ammonia to water) from the absorber 
tank.
When heated, the ammonia in the strong 
solution begins to vaporize, creating 
bubbles with a percolating effect.
The ammonia vapor pushes the now 
weakened solution up and out of the perk 
tube.
Ammonia Vapor Travels to 
Condenser
The ammonia vapor (gas) leaving the perk 
tube goes upward towards the top of the 
cooling unit.
Little of the water vapor travels upwards 
because ammonia vaporizes at a lower 
temperature than water, causing the two 
to separate.
A rectifier, and sometimes a water 
separator, catches the little water that 
vaporizes.
Weak Solution Travels Back to 
Absorber
As rich vaporized ammonia travels to the 
condenser, the now weakened, still warm 
solution flows downward to the top of the 
absorber coils and enters the absorber 
tank at a cooler temperature.
When flowing downward through the coil, 
the weak solution picks up evaporated 
ammonia from the evaporator. This 
absorption process generates heat that is 
dissipated through the absorber fins.
Flow of Refrigerant: Step 2
Ammonia Vapor Cools in 
Condenser
Ammonia vapor enters the condenser 
where it undergoes cooling by air passing 
through the condenser metal fins at the rear 
of the refrigerator.
The cooling effect of the condenser, 
coupled with a series of reductions in pipe 
size, forces the ammonia vapor into a liquid 
state, where it enters the evaporator 
section.
Liquid Ammonia Evaporates When 
It Contacts Pressurized Hydrogen
Liquid ammonia coming in contact with 
pressurized hydrogen absorbs heat and 
evaporates. This is the principle whereby 
the heat is absorbed from both the freezer 
and refrigerator boxes.
Liquid ammonia enters the low temperature 
evaporator (freezer) and trickles down the 
pipe, wetting the walls. Hydrogen passes 
over the wetted walls, causing the liquid 
ammonia to evaporate at an initial 
temperature of around -20°F (-29°C).
The Ammonia Vapor and 
Hydrogen Drop to the Absorber 
Tank
The ammonia vapor created through the 
evaporation mixes with the already present 
hydrogen vapor, making it heavier.
Since the ammonia and hydrogen vapor 
mixture is heavier than the purer hydrogen, 
it drops down through the return tube to the 
absorber tank.
Flow of Refrigerant: Final Step
Strong Solution Absorbs 
Ammonia Vapor
When the ammonia and hydrogen 
vapor mixture enters the absorber 
tank through the return tube, much 
of the ammonia vapor is absorbed 
into the surface of the strong 
solution, which occupies the lower 
half of the tank.
Hydrogen Returns to the 
Evaporator
Now lighter, the ammonia and 
hydrogen mixture (now with less 
ammonia) begins to rise up the 
absorber coil. The weak ammonia 
solution trickling down the absorber 
coil from the top is "hungry" for the 
ammonia vapor that is rising up the 
absorber coil with the hydrogen.
Cycle Continues
This weak ammonia solution 
eventually absorbs all the ammonia 
from the mixture as it rises, allowing 
pure hydrogen to rise up the inner 
pipe of the evaporator section, 
completing the cycle.
Generator Components
Although various brands and models use different components, configured in vastly different ways, this drawing represents a 
standard refrigerator propane generator system. The test port (shown closed) is visible in the diagram.
Modern Generator Assembly
Electronic Ignition
Modern refrigerators use electronic 
ignition systems that are more reliable 
and efficient than older manual 
systems.
Electronic Sensing
Temperature sensors provide 
feedback to the control system, 
allowing for precise temperature 
control and improved efficiency.
Thermostatic Valve
The amount of cooling depends on the amount of heat produced by the flame. The 
higher the flame, the faster the cooling, and vice versa.
The thermostatic valve senses the temperature of the evaporator (through the 
thermostat capillary) and varies the heat input (by modulating the gas pressure delivered 
to the burner) to make the operation automatic.
This ensures that the correct temperature is maintained in the refrigerator.
Thermostatic Valve Components
Manual Selector
For electrical or gas operation. 
Most absorption refrigerators 
can operate either on propane 
gas or electricity. Some units 
have automatic energy selectors 
that automatically choose the 
most appropriate source of 
power.
Thermostat Control
When the thermostat calls for 
cooling, the maximum pressure 
of propane is allowed through 
the orifice of the burner. The 
thermostat control adjusts the 
amount of pressure admitted 
and, thus, controls the size of the 
flame and the amount of heat 
generated.
Bypass Screw
When the desired temperature is 
reached, the thermostat blocks 
the "open" pathway and routes 
the propane through the bypass 
circuit. The bypass section only 
allows a very small amount of gas 
through, just enough to keep the 
thermocouple and the 
refrigeration system heated.
More Thermostatic Valve 
Components
Pressure Tap
For most propane-fired refrigerators, the correct gas inlet pressure is 11 
inches w.c. Referring to the manufacturer's specifications can help 
determine the exact pressure. This appliance is probably the most 
sensitive when it comes to gas pressure; there is very little tolerance in the 
gas pressure before problems begin.
Thermostatic Control Mechanism
Operates in relation to the temperature of the evaporator fins. With the 
safety device open, the gas flows normally through the main passage up to 
the thermostat operating mechanism. By increasing the temperature at 
the evaporator, the gas inside the thermostat capillary increases in 
pressure, causing the set and pin to rise.
Orifice and Orifice Housing
Function
The orifice controls the amount of gas injected into the 
burner. The main function of the orifice housing is to provide 
a correct air-gas ratio. As the diameters of the air and gas

In regard to gas refrigerator, the term venting has multiple meanings. To properly understand the 
venting requirement, it is necessary to understand the three different venting requirements of the 
refrigerator. These include: 
• ventilation air flow across the fins for the removal of heat;

Ventilation ( cooling) air flow

refrigerant; it is, therefore, essential that proper venting occurs behind the refrigerator. If the heat

from the cooling unit and rise.

3. Maintenance and servicing 
Overview 
Purpose 
The key factors for ensuring that domestic gas-fired refrigerators operate properly are that the 
refrigerator: 
• is level; 
• has the correct input; and 
• has proper air circulation to dissipate the heat generated. 
If these three conditions are met, the refrigerator should operate successfully. 
Objectives 
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to: 
• describe the biannual cleaning and servicing procedures; and 
• describe the troubleshooting procedures. 
Terminology

Cleaning and servicing 
To maintain a safe and efficient operation, gas-fired absorption refrigerators should be serviced 
and maintained twice a year, preferably before a season of continued use and especially if the 
refrigerator has been not in use for some time. 
When servicing gas-fired absorption refrigerators, ensure that the gas supply pressure is correct. 
Condenser fins and absorber 
Periodical cleaning of fins on the condenser is a must to ensure good heat removal from these 
surfaces. 
September 2020 
41
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 16 
Domestic gas-fired refrigerators 
To check and clean the condenser fins and absorber, follow this procedure: 
1) 
Move the refrigerator away from its permanent location, making sure the flexible connector 
does not kink. 
2) 
Clean dust buildup on the absorber and condenser, which can lessen the heat transfer and 
impair performance: 
a) 
Remove the dust from the refrigerator and the enclosure. 
b) 
Clean the condenser using a paintbrush. 
Flue system 
After a period of operation, the flue may require cleaning. A dirty flue causes a reduction in rapid 
heat transfer from the gas flame to the generator body. Periodic cleaning of the flue is then 
needed to: 
• ensure proper refrigeration; 
• reduce gas consumption; and 
• prevent incomplete combustion and the generation of carbon monoxide (CO). 
The following procedure for cleaning the flue is typical of that given in manufacturer's 
instructions. In all cases, be sure to place papers or cloth under the refrigerator to collect dirt or 
debris. 
1) 
Cover the burner with a cloth. 
2) 
Loosen and remove the flue extension. 
3) 
Remove the baffle assembly. 
-
Clean and inspect this assembly. The baffle may contain burnt dust and light surface 
corrosion. The tip, however, must be intact, not corroded. Soot must not be present, as 
this is a sign of incomplete combustion. Should this soot occur, contact the dealer or 
manufacturer. 
4) 
Run the brush through the flame tube. Soot must not appear. 
5) 
Reassemble the baffle checking its extension, if necessary. 
6) 
Assemble the flue extension, making sure that the wire of the baffle fits into the baffle's slot. 
7) 
Remove the cloth from the burner. 
8) 
Reinstall the burner box. 
9) 
Check the refrigerator operation. 
Servicing basics 
In absorption refrigerator servicing, there are three factors that must be kept in balance: 
• heat input; 
• air circulation; and 
• levelling. 
r 
t 
The manufacturer designs the refrigerator so that the maximum input setting is high enough for 
the unit to respond quickly to added loads but not so high that the generator is scorched or 
42 
September 2020
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 16 
Domestic gas-fired refrigerators 
blistered . The minimum input setting is low enough to prevent over-cooling but not so low as to 
allow the flame to be blown out by drafts. 
To ensure proper heat input, conduct the following checks: 
1) 
You can check the gas pressure using a manometer at the pressure tap (on the thermostatic 
valve) and correct it by adjusting the regulator at the cylinder. 
2) 
If the orifice is partially blocked, you can clean or replace the orifice. 
3) 
Clean or replace the filter in the gas control inlet side. 
4) 
If the flame impinges on a surface or is burning yellow, the generator and flue passages will 
become coated with soot and needs to be cleaned for rapid heat transfer. Ensure that you do 
not damage the generator surfaces. 
Proper air circulation 
To ensure proper air circulation, air flow to and from the unit must not be restricted . 
Ensure that: 
• the back of the refrigerator is the correct distance from the wall; and 
• foreign objects have not fallen into the space. 
The cooling fins of both the condenser and the absorber must be free of dirt and lint, which would 
hamper the flow of air and the release of heat to the atmosphere. 
Proper levelling 
Keep the system level during installation and maintenance, allowing liquids to flow in the proper 
direction so that heat is absorbed and released according to the system's design. 
It is important that the evaporator is level so that the liquid ammonia is spread out over a large 
area. This allows the heat to be drawn efficiently from the refrigerator cabinet. 
If a unit is temporarily unused, it may fail to start to cool on the first try. The traps may empty of 
liquid, with the ammonia vapour blocking the tubes in the wrong places. To overcome this 
condition, some manufacturers recommend one of the following methods: 
1) 
Shut the unit off for several hours, allowing all the ammonia vapour to condense and flow 
back to the generator and to fill the liquid traps. 
2) 
After about 10 minutes of operation, tilt the unit to the left for 30 seconds, then to the right for 
30 seconds. 
3) 
Repeat above step three or four times, then put the refrigerator in the upright, level position. 
If the unit is not defective, it should begin freezing. 
The circulation of the refrigerant through the cooling unit is accomplished by gravity flow; 
therefore, the refrigerator must be operated in the level position. Off-level operation affects the 
flow of the refrigerant through the cooling system. 
The maximum off-level operation limits are: 
• 3 degrees from side-to-side; and 
• 6 degrees from front-to-back. 
September 2020 
43
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 16 
Domestic gas-fired refrigerators 
Exceeding the maximum off-level limits can permanently damage the cooling unit. In mobile gas-
fired refrigerators, the cooling unit or its performance are not affected when the vehicle is in 
motion. 
Testing components 
The following information on testing components is intended to give a broad understanding of the 
basic process. Specific manufacturer's instructions for component testing will be provided in the 
service manual. 
C() sensor \cvith safetv shut-off 
.,; 
For units supplied with a CO sensor, manufacturers recommend testing the alarm operation at 
least once per week during use or if the appliance has been turned off for a period of time. 
The following procedure is typical of a manufacturer's instruction on how to test a carbon 
monoxide sensor: 
1) 
Push and hold the test button down until a "beep" is heard, then release button. 
2) 
Unit will test measurement circuit for correct operation. 
3) 
At the end of the test, the unit will sound a three-second test confirmation beep and resume 
normal operation. 
The test will shut down the gas supply to the appliance so it will need to be re-lit to resume 
operation. 
Flan1e--failurc device 
Check the operation of the flame-failure device as follows: 
1) 
With the refrigerator running, set the thermostat to the coldest setting. 
2) 
Close and then immediately open the selector valve. The flame will go out, but the gas 
supply will continue to flow. 
3) 
Listen carefully. In about 30 to 40 seconds, you will hear a slight but very distinct "click" to 
signify that the valve has closed. 
Replacing components 
The following information on replacing components is intended to give a broad understanding of 
the basic process. Specific manufacturer's instructions for component replacement will be 
provided in the service manual. 
Orifice (injector) housing 
Disassembling the nipple holder with two open-end spanners can help take off the orifice 
(injector). Follow this procedure when replacing the orifice housing: 
1) 
Take off the injector piece and check whether it is obstructed. 
2) 
Clean with alcohol and compressed air. 
3) 
Before reassembling, tap gently a few times on the gas tube leading to the burner to loosen 
any lint collected in the tube. 
4) 
Reassemble and tighten carefully. 
44

Domestic gas-fired refrigerators 
Burner 
Depending on the type of refrigerator, the burner assembly can be a gas only or a combination 
gas-electric unit. 
To replace a gas only burner, do the following: 
1) 
Remove the cover by removing the screws. 
2) 
Unscrew the burner jet. 
3) 
Remove the burner by removing the mounting screw. 
4) 
Insert replacement burner that is the same make and model. 
5) 
Reassemble the mounting screw and cover. 
To replace a gas-electric burner, follow this procedure: 
1) 
Remove the covers by removing the screws. 
2) 
Disconnect the heater cords at the terminal blocks (note the location for later reassembly). 
3) 
To avoid damaging the capillary tube, remove it carefully from the evaporator. 
4) 
Remove the screws. 
5) 
Release the burner housing from the flue by turning the lever outwards and to the right. 
6) 
Pull the equipment out from the cabinet. 
7) 
Replace the burner with the same make and model. 
Additional components 
The following components also affect the overall performance of a refrigerator and should be 
tested and serviced during a call. 
Refer to the manufacturer's service manual for cleaning, testing, and servicing instructions for 
these components: 
• cabinet and absorber fan motors; 
• door switches; 
• cabinet lights; 
• heaters; 
• defrost switch; 
• door seal; 
• refrigeration unit; and 
• defrost heater and safety switch.
